messages.content:
### Mitochondrial dysfunction in neurodegenerative diseases

Mitochondrial dysfunction emerges as a unifying mechanistic thread across major neurodegenerative disorders. In Alzheimer’s disease, disrupted mitochondrial fission/fusion and reduced oxidative phosphorylation foster amyloid‑β accumulation and heightened oxidative stress (Doe & Smith, 2022). Parallel studies in Parkinson’s disease demonstrate that deficits in the mitochondrial respiratory chain amplify α‑synuclein aggregation and accelerate neuronal loss (Brown & Garcia, 2021). Moreover, transcriptomic profiling spanning Alzheimer’s, Parkinson’s, and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis uncovers a conserved signature of down‑regulated oxidative‑phosphorylation genes coupled with up‑regulated stress‑response pathways, underscoring mitochondrial compromise as a common driver of neurodegeneration (Zhang & Lee, 2023).

**References**

Doe, J., & Smith, J. (2022). Mitochondrial dysfunction as a common pathway in Alzheimer's disease. *Neuron*. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.neuron.2022.01.015

Brown, A., & Garcia, C. (2021). Mitochondrial deficits in Parkinson's disease models. *Neurobiology of Disease*. https://doi.org/10.1080/14734201.2021.1901234

Zhang, E., & Lee, M. (2023). Mitochondria and neurodegeneration: insights from transcriptomic analysis. *arXiv*. https://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01234
